description: Former Georgia congressman Tom Price resigned as Secretary of HHS on Sept. 29, 2017 after tumultuous eight months in the Trump administration.
title: Photos: Tom Price, former Secretary of Health and Human Services
title_page: Photos: Tom Price, former Secretary of Health and Human Services

The Atlanta Journal-Constitution Vice President Mike Pence, right, administers the oath of office Friday to Tom Price to become the nation’s 23rd secretary of health and human services. southernheritagepac.org After Republicans in the state Capitol cut a deal with Democrats to avoid a statewide referendum on the 1956 state flag and its Confederate battle emblem, critics produced a deck of cards with the faces of white lawmakers who had opposed them. Cliff Owen/AP In this file photo, House Budget Committee Chairman Rep. Tom Price, R-Ga. holds-up a synopsis of the House Republican budget proposal as he announces the plan on Capitol Hill in Washington, Tuesday, March 17, 2015. The plan included a boost in defense spending but cuts in the Medicaid program for the poor, food stamps and health care subsidies.

Tom Price, R-Ga., right, accompanied by committee Chairman Paul Ryan, R-Wis., left, and other committee members, speaks during a news conference on Capitol Hill in Washington, Wednesday, Dec. 7, 2011, to unveil a "comprehensive reform effort aimed to repair the broken budget process".

J. Scott Applewhite/AP In this Jan. 13, 2015 file photo, House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Rep. Paul Ryan, R-Wis., left, joined by Rep. Tom Price, R-Ga., heads to a meeting of House Republicans on Capitol Hill in Washington. When President-elect Donald Trump takes office in January, Republicans will have the opportunity to do something they have desired for years - overhaul Medicaid, the program that provides health care to millions of lower-income and disabled Americans. Republicans have argued that states have little incentive to keep expenses under control, because no state pays more than half the total cost. Both Ryan and Trump's pick for secretary of health and human services, Price, want to switch to block grants.

J. Scott Applewhite/AP Rep. Tom Price, R-Ga., center, flanked by Rep. Mike Kelly, R-Pa., left, and Rep. Mark Meadows, R-N.C., speaks during a news conference on Capitol Hill in Washington, Friday, Aug. 2, 2013, about his bill, the "Keep the IRS Off Your Health Care Act," which the House passed and targets President Barack Obama's health care overhaul. The bill aims to prevent the Internal Revenue Service from implementing any part of the health care law. It is the 40th time the Republican-controlled House has tried to block the Affordable Care Act, popularly known as Obamacare.
